facts.text: Criminal Appeals Nos. 50-52 of 1964 were filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeals Nos. 50-52 of 1964. Appeals from the judgment and order dated January 17, 24, 1964 of the Bombay High Court in Criminal Appeals Nos. 961 to 963 of 1962.

facts.text: Appeals from Bombay High Court judgment and order dated January 17, 24, 1964 in Criminal Appeals Nos. 961 to 963 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgment and order dated January 17, 24, 1964 of the Bombay High Court in Criminal Appeals Nos. 961 to 963 of 1962. K. Sen, R. Jethmalani, Jethmalani, Kumar M. Mehta, B. Parthasarathy and J. B. Dadachanji, for the appellants  in Cr. A. No. 50 of 1964 .

facts.text: Three brothers (appellants) convicted under S. 120-B IPC and s. 167(81) Sea Customs Act with imprisonment and fine.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Hidayatullah, J. The appellants who are three brothers appeal by certificate against their conviction under S. 120-B of the Indian Penal Code and s. 167 81  of the Sea Customs Act and the sentences of imprisonment and fine respectively imposed on them.

facts.text: Fourth brother filed Criminal Appeal No. 55 of 1964 but did not press it at the hearing.

anchor.surface_text: A ,fourth brother had filed Criminal Appeal No. 55 of 1964 but did number press it at the hearing. One other person  S. L. Daga  was also convicted with them but has number appealed.

facts.text: S. L. Daga convicted with appellants but did not appeal.

anchor.surface_text: One other person  S. L. Daga  was also convicted with them but has number appealed. These persons were found to have entered into a criminal conspiracy among themselves and with others including one Yau Mockchi, a Chinese citizen in Hong Kong, to smuggle gold into India.

facts.text: Appellants conspired with others including Yau Mockchi to smuggle gold into India.

anchor.surface_text: These persons were found to have entered into a criminal conspiracy among themselves and with others including one Yau Mockchi, a Chinese citizen in Hong Kong, to smuggle gold into India. The method adopted was to insert strips of gold  about 250 tolas  under the .lining of the lid of a suitcase, which could be retrieved by unscrewing the metal comer supports and pulling on strings attached to the strips.

facts.text: Method: insert strips of gold (250 tolas) under suitcase lid lining, retrieved by unscrewing supports and pulling strings.

anchor.surface_text: The method adopted was to insert strips of gold  about 250 tolas  under the .lining of the lid of a suitcase, which could be retrieved by unscrewing the metal comer supports and pulling on strings attached to the strips. The suitcases were brought into India by air stewardnesses, and Ethyl Wong  P.W. 1 , an Anglo-Chinese girl employed by Air India, was one of them.

facts.text: Suitcases brought into India by air stewardesses including Ethyl Wong (PW1, Anglo-Chinese, Air India employee).

anchor.surface_text: The suitcases were brought into India by air stewardnesses, and Ethyl Wong  P.W. 1 , an Anglo-Chinese girl employed by Air India, was one of them. Discovery came, after gold was successfully smuggled on many occasions, when Yau Mockch approached one Sophia Wong of the O.A.C. line.

facts.text: Gold smuggled successfully on many occasions before discovery.

anchor.surface_text: Discovery came, after gold was successfully smuggled on many occasions, when Yau Mockch approached one Sophia Wong of the O.A.C. line. She was engaged to a police officer and informed her superior officers. A trap was laid.

facts.text: Yau Mockchi approached Sophia Wong (O.A.C. line), who informed superiors; trap laid and Yau caught with gold suitcase.

anchor.surface_text: when Yau Mockch approached one Sophia Wong of the O.A.C. line. She was engaged to a police officer and informed her superior officers. A trap was laid. Yau Mockchi was caught with a suit-case with gold in it after he had explained to Sophia how the gold was inserted and how it could be taken out.

facts.text: On search of Yau Mockchi, visiting cards of Ethyl Wong and Laxmipat Choraria, photos of Laxmipat and Balchand Choraria, addresses, phone numbers, incriminating letters, accounts, cables found.

anchor.surface_text: On the search of his person and also of his place of business, visiting cards of several persons including those of Ethyl Wong and Laxmipat Choraria  Crl. Appeal 50/64 , photographs of Laxmipat and Balchand Choraria  Crl. Appeal No. 52/64 , their addresses and telephone numbers, and other incriminating letters, accounts, cables, etc., were found.

facts.text: Raids in India and Hong Kong; Kundanmal Choraria and S.L. Daga running Global Agencies; documents, codes, account books seized, some photostated.

anchor.surface_text: Immediately thereafter raids took place in India and at Hong Kong where the other two accused who are number before us  Kundanmal Choraria and S. L. Daga  were running a firm called Global Agencies. Numerous documents  some in simple code  and account books were seized. Many of these documents were photostated.

facts.text: Original documents returned under Supreme Court of Hong Kong orders and suppressed.

anchor.surface_text: The originals were unfortunately returned under the orders of the Supreme Court of Hong Kong and have since been suppressed. On the strength of these materials the prosecution was started.

facts.text: Ethyl Wong examined as first witness, gave account of conspiracy; accomplice testimony.

anchor.surface_text: At the commencement of the trial Ethyl Wong was examined as the first witness and gave a graphic account of the conspiracy and the parts played by the accused and her own share in the transactions. Her testimony was clearly that of an accomplice

facts.text: Ethyl Wong not prosecuted, testimony questioned but admitted as corroborated.

anchor.surface_text: Although she could have been prosecuted, she was number arraigned and it is her testimony which has been the subject of a major part of the arguments before us. No effort has been spared to have it excluded.

facts.text: Prosecution started on strength of seized materials.

anchor.surface_text: On the strength of these materials the prosecution was started.

facts.text: Ethyl Wong carried gold for Yau Mockchi on several occasions, corroborated.

anchor.surface_text: Ethyl Wong admittedly carried gold for Yau Mockchi on several occasions. She admitted this in court and her evidence receives ample corroboration as to the mode employed from the statement of Sophia Wong and the seizure of the suitcase

facts.text: Ethyl Wong's first statement Ex.1 on December 27, 1960 admitting involvement.

anchor.surface_text: On December 27, 1960 Ethyl Won- landed at the Bombay Air Terminal. Two customs officers were waiting for her and questioned her. It was then that Ethyl Wong made her first statement  Ex. 1  admitting her own share, in the smuggling racket set up by Yau Mockchi.

facts.text: Second statement Ex.2 on December 29, 1960 correcting inaccuracies.

anchor.surface_text: On December 29, 1960 she gave a second statement  Ex. 2  and corrected certain inaccuracies in her first statement. On January 2, 1961 she was examined as the first prosecution witness.

facts.text: Complaint filed on April 6, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: The complaint was filed in court on April 6, 1960 and the case was to commence on January 2, 1961.

facts.text: Court accepts Ethyl Wong's evidence as corroborated and reliable.

anchor.surface_text: Apart from the fact that the High Court and the, court below have concurrently believed it already, we find ample corroboration for it from her own previous statements made without warning, her pointing out the flats where she delivered gold, her cable written in code to inform the parties in Hong Kong after successful smuggling, her visiting card in the possession of Yau Mockchi, the passenger manifests showing her trips, the entries in the hotel registers and the telephone calls made by her to the flat of the accused and so on and so forth.

facts.text: Photostats of documents used as originals suppressed.

anchor.surface_text: The photostats have been proved to our satisfaction to be genuine photographs of the letters. The copies were made through the Indian Embassy and bore the certificate.

facts.text: Appeals dismissed by Supreme Court.

holdings.text: Ethyl Wong was a competent witness under S. 118 of the Indian Evidence Act.

anchor.surface_text: Now there can be nodoubt that Ethyl Wong was a competent witness. Under S. 118 of the Indian Evidence Act all persons are competent to testify unless the

holdings.reasoning_summary: All persons competent unless unable to understand questions; applies directly to Ethyl Wong as witness.

holdings.text: Under S. 132 Evidence Act, witness compelled to answer incriminating questions but protected from prosecution thereon except perjury.

anchor.surface_text: Under S. 132 a witness shall not be excused from answering any question as to any matter relevant to the matter in issue in any criminal proceeding  among others

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory compulsion with proviso protection; distinguishes from accused.

holdings.text: Article 20(3) protects only accused persons, not witnesses; waived if voluntarily testifying.

anchor.surface_text: The protection is further fortified by Art. 20 3  which says that no person accused of any offence shall be compelled to be a witness against himself.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation limits to accused; witness position different.

holdings.text: Accomplice is competent witness under S. 133 Evidence Act; corroboration rule of caution applies.

anchor.surface_text: Section 133 of the Evidence Act makes the accomplice a competent witness against an accused person. Therefore, Ethyl Wongs testimony was again that of a

holdings.text: S. 5 Indian Oaths Act exclusionary clause applies only to accused person actually on trial, not potential accomplice witness.

anchor.surface_text: no oath could be administered to her as she was an accused person since s. 5 of the Indian Oaths Act bars such a course and (b) it was the duty of the prosecution

holdings.reasoning_summary: Historical context, interrelation with CrPC ss.342,342A, Evidence s.132; precedents support examining non-prosecuted accomplice.

holdings.text: No duty on prosecution or Magistrate to try accomplice jointly; trial not vitiated.

anchor.surface_text: and (b) it was the duty of the prosecution and or the Magistrate to have tried Ethyl Wong jointly with the appellants L2SupCI./68-10 The breach of the last obligation, it is submitted, vitiated the trial

holdings.reasoning_summary: Non-cognizable customs offences; Magistrate cognizance on complaint, no police investigation.

holdings.text: Pardon provisions Ch.XXIV CrPC do not apply to these offences; no bar to examining accomplice otherwise.

anchor.surface_text: Next it is submitted that as the provisions relating to tender of pardon to accomplices contained in Chapter XXIV of the Code do not apply to offences under

holdings.reasoning_summary: Offences not covered by ss.337,338 applicability.

holdings.text: No obligation to convict/withdraw prosecution to obtain accomplice testimony; s.132 protects.

anchor.surface_text: the only two ways in which Ethyl Wongs testimony could have been obtained was either to take her plea of guilty and convict and sentence her or to withdraw

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prosecution discretion; public interest in breaking smuggling ring.

holdings.text: Photostats of documents admissible as evidence of contents and handwriting if genuine, no trickery, originals suppressed.

anchor.surface_text: The photostats have been proved to our satisfaction to be genuine photographs of the letters. The copies were made through the Indian Embassy and bore the certificate.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Common practice; precedents/Wigmore; s.10 Evidence Act context; embassy certification.

holdings.text: Letter Z-217 treated as genuine specimen for handwriting comparison.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Recovered from ancestral home; domestic references corroborated; unlikely forged.

holdings.text: Ethyl Wong's identification reliable despite prior photo viewing.

anchor.surface_text: The next question is whether Ethyl Wongs identification of Laxmipat and Balchand, whose photographs were shown to her at the Air Terminal at Bombay should be accepted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Independent corroboration: names/descriptions pre-photos, flat pointed, phone records, card description.

holdings.text: No violation of Arts. 14 and 20 in examining accomplice.

anchor.surface_text: The last contention that there has been discrimination and violation of Arts. 14 and 20 is without substance. Reliance was placed on S. G. Jaisinghani v.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.337 not violative; accomplice evidence essential, not arbitrary selection.

holdings.text: S. 10 Evidence Act applies once conspiracy proved; admits co-conspirator acts/statements.

anchor.surface_text: The case was one under s. 120-B of the Indian Penal Code. As the existence of a conspiracy is proved beyond a shadow of doubt, s. 10 of the Indian Evidence Act

holdings.reasoning_summary: Conspiracy existence established; section directly attracted.

holdings.text: Ethyl Wong's accomplice testimony sufficiently corroborated.

anchor.surface_text: Apart from the fact that the High Court and the, court below have concurrently believed it already, we find ample corroboration for it from her own previous statements

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prior statements, pointing flats, coded cable, visiting card, manifests, hotel registers, calls.
